item.description:

item.title: The UK has emerged victorious in a battle with the financial services industry and the European Central Bank, but the question remains: can it secure victory in the overall war?
item.description:
Steve Peers Until recently, the EU courts seemed to consistently rule against the UK in cases related to financial services and opt-outs from EU law. However, a recent General Court judgment regarding the UK’s challenge to the European Central Bank (ECB) policy on securities clearing systems has defied these trends. This begs the questions: what does this mean for the UK’s financial services sector, and for the UK’s relationship with the EU?..

item.title: New discoveries in the "Mellifera" case shed light on access to environmental justice under the Aarhus Regulation, but the underlying issues remain unchanged.
item.description:
Mario Pagano, PhD candidate in EU environmental law, European University Institute Background The Aarhus Convention is a crucial piece of international law concerning environmental democracy rights. Established in 1998, this UN Convention lays out three procedural rights directly connected to environmental protection: the right to environmental information, the right to participate in environmental decision-making, and the right to legal recourse on environmental issues (the three Aarhus “pillars”). The Aarhus Convention Compliance Committee (ACCC), formed in Geneva in 2002, ensures that the legislation of the Convention’s Parties aligns with the Convention itself...

item.title: The EU General Court has declared Adidas' three-stripe trademark to be invalid.
item.description:
Alexandros Antoniou, a legal expert from the University of Essex, analyzes a June 19, 2019, ruling by the EU General Court (GC) that invalidated Adidas’s trademark of three parallel stripes. The court upheld the EU Intellectual Property Office’s decision, which found the trademark too simplistic and lacking distinctiveness, both inherently and through use. Adidas’s trademark, registered on May 21, 2014, for apparel, footwear, and headgear, was challenged by Shoe Branding Europe BVBA in December 2014...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/the-eu-general-court-has-declared-adidas-three-stripe-trademark-to-be-invalid/

item.title: The General Court has made a ruling on the European Citizens' Initiative, stating that the Commission must provide reasons for refusing to register proposals.
item.description:
Anastasia Karatzia, Assistant Professor in EU law, Erasmus School of Law Introduction On February 3rd, the General Court (GC) overturned a European Commission decision for the first time, determining that the Commission failed to provide sufficient justification when it denied registration to a proposed European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI). This concise judgment in the Minority SafePack case concerns procedural matters within the relatively new ECI, which was established in 2012. The judgment offers valuable insight to those interested in the ECI and, more broadly, in opportunities for citizens to participate in EU lawmaking...
